title: ExperimentalMarkdownSyntaxTextSplitter does not reset lower-level headers when higher-level ones are introduced
author: m-t-chang
body:
### Checked other resources

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it.
- [x] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.
- [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).
- [x] I posted a self-contained, minimal, reproducible example. A maintainer can copy it and run it AS IS.

### Example Code

```python
from langchain_text_splitters.markdown import ExperimentalMarkdownSyntaxTextSplitter

text = """
# Example Document Title

### Subsection Header

This paragraph should have two headings, one for the document title and one for the subsection.

## Section Header

This paragraph should have two headings, one for the document title and one for the section, but it incorrectly gets assigned the subsection header as well.
"""

splitter = ExperimentalMarkdownSyntaxTextSplitter()
sections = splitter.split_text(text)

for sec in sections:
    print(sec.metadata)
    print(sec.page_content)
    print("-" * 100)
```

### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable)

_No response_

### Description

I'm trying to use ExperimentalMarkdownSyntaxTextSplitter to split markdown documents, but I noticed that it handles headers in an unexpected way. In the example above, I would expect the second paragraph to only have the level 1 (Document Title) and level 2 (Section) headers, but it still has the previous level 3 (Subsection) header, even though that level 3 header is not hierarchically under the current level 2 header.

Output of running the above code:
```
{'Header 1': 'Example Document Title', 'Header 3': 'Subsection Header'}

This paragraph should have two headings, one for the document title and one for the subsection.


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
{'Header 1': 'Example Document Title', 'Header 3': 'Subsection Header', 'Header 2': 'Section Header'}

This paragraph should have two headings, one for the document title and one for the section, but it incorrectly gets assigned the subsection header as well.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
```

comments.body:
The problem was that when splitting markdown, the `ExperimentalMarkdownSyntaxTextSplitter` was keeping old headers (like ###) even after a new higher-level header (like ##) appeared. This caused chunks to have the wrong metadata.

I updated the `_resolve_header_stack` function to remove any headers that are at the same or deeper level before adding the new one. This way, each chunk only keeps the correct headers in its metadata.

title: React agent with ChatOpenAI doesn't stream tool call args on "message" stream mode
author: teshnizi
body:
### Checked other resources

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it.
- [x] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.
- [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).
- [x] I posted a self-contained, minimal, reproducible example. A maintainer can copy it and run it AS IS.

### Example Code

The following code 

```python


@tool
def add_numbers(a: int, b: int) -> int:
    """Add two numbers."""
    return a + b


async def main():
    model = ChatOpenAI(model="gpt-4o-mini")
    agent = create_react_agent(model, [add_numbers])

    input_data = {
        "messages": [HumanMessage(content="What is 5 + 3? also what's 8 + 4?")]
    }

    async for stream_mode, chunk in agent.astream(
        input_data, stream_mode=["messages", "updates"]
    ):

        if stream_mode == "messages":
            print("CHUNK:", chunk[0].tool_calls)
            print("---")

        if stream_mode == "updates":
            print("UPDATES CHUNK:", chunk)
            print("---")


if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())

```



### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable)


generates this output:

```

title: DOC: with_structured_output => example of setting enum
author: nick-youngblut
body:
### URL

https://python.langchain.com/docs/how_to/structured_output/

### Checklist

- [X] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [X] I included a link to the documentation page I am referring to (if applicable).

### Issue with current documentation:

It would be helpful to show how to restrict the model output to a set of values (enum). This can be tricky for a new user of langchain, given the lack of python code examples at both the langchain docs and the [OpenAI API docs](https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/structured-outputs).

### Idea or request for content:

_No response_

comments.body:
Also, the langchain docs seem to conflict with the OpenAI docs. [Langchain docs](https://python.langchain.com/docs/how_to/structured_output/):

> If we want the model to return a Pydantic object, we just need to pass in the desired Pydantic class. The key advantage of using Pydantic is that the model-generated output will be validated. Pydantic will raise an error if any required fields are missing or if any fields are of the wrong type.

[OpenAI docs](https://cookbook.openai.com/examples/structured_outputs_intro): 

> Structured Outputs is a new capability in the Chat Completions API and Assistants API that guarantees the model will always generate responses that adhere to your supplied JSON Schema. In this cookbook, we will illustrate this capability with a few examples.

If the model is guaranteed to generate output that adheres to the supplied schema, then why would the model output need to be validated? 

It would help to point out that `.with_structured_output(strict=True)` will provide the behavior specified in the [OpenAI docs](https://cookbook.openai.com/examples/structured_outputs_intro).

How is this a conflict, the Pydantic Object allows us to do validation and easily pass in the schema for your model output. Think of it as an easier way of passing and validating the schema. As you can see [here](https://vscode.dev/github/keenborder786/langchain/blob/master/libs/partners/openai/langchain_openai/chat_models/base.py#L1416) that passed pydantic model is convert to a dict as per OpenAI Specification behind the scenes. It's just an easier way to pass in the schema. 

As far as the `strict` attribute is concern it is mentioned in the docstring [here](https://vscode.dev/github/keenborder786/langchain/blob/master/libs/partners/openai/langchain_openai/chat_models/base.py#L1174).

Also just so we are on the same page `with_structured_output ` behind the use OpenAI Tool API to get a desired output in a given format and then using either `PydanticOutputParser` and `JsonOutputParser` we get output in a structured manner. My point is in actuality langchain is using the same Tool API provided by Open AI but has a custom parser which gives a structured output.

> How is this a conflict, the Pydantic Object allows us to do validation and easily pass in the schema for your model output.

For OpenAI models, structured output forces the models to output the correct schema, so no further validation is necessary for those particular models, correct? From the OpenAI blog post: 

> Structured Outputs is a new capability in the Chat Completions API and Assistants API that guarantees the model will always generate responses that adhere to your supplied JSON Schema

...so then no need for "...model-generated output will be validated". AFAIK, this currently only applies to OpenAI models, but it could be helpful to add a short section in the docs on this, and also on the use of `strict`. I get that `strict` is described in the docstrings (it would be troubling if there were no docstrings on that parameter), but such logic of "it's already desribed in the docstrings" would negate much of the need for the [langchain docs](https://python.langchain.com/docs/introduction/).

I'm sorry if I'm not fully groking the docs and langchain implementation of the `with_structured_output`. I'm just trying to provide a perspective from a naive user.

title: Splitting Text from Huggingface Tokenizer uses encode function for calcuating length, which counts at least 2 extra tokens per text unit being merged
author: keshavshrikant
body:
### Checked other resources

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I searched the LangChain documentation with the integrated search.
- [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it.
- [x] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.
- [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).

### Example Code

```python
from langchain_text_splitters import RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter
from transformers import AutoTokenizer

tokenizer = AutoTokenizer.from_pretrained("BAAI/BGE-M3")

default_splitter = RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter.from_huggingface_tokenizer(
    tokenizer=tokenizer, chunk_size=256, chunk_overlap=128
)

new_splitter = RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter.from_huggingface_tokenizer(
    tokenizer=tokenizer, chunk_size=256, chunk_overlap=128
)
new_splitter._length_function = lambda x: len(tokenizer.tokenize(x))

sample_text = """Yes, you can replace **quinoa** with **rice** or **wheat**, but itâ€™s important to understand the differences between these grains to make an informed choice:  ---### **Quinoa vs. Rice vs. Wheat**  | **Nutrient**          | **Quinoa**                  | **Rice** (White/Brown)       | **Wheat** (Whole Grain)    |  |------------------------|-----------------------------|-----------------------------|---------------------------|  | **Protein**            | High, contains all 9 essential amino acids | Lower (especially white rice) | Moderate (higher in whole wheat) |  | **Fiber**              | High (especially for digestion) | Low (white rice), Moderate (brown rice) | High (whole wheat) |  | **Gluten-Free**        | Yes                         | Yes                         | No (contains gluten)      |  | **Micronutrients**     | High in magnesium, iron, and B-vitamins | Moderate in nutrients (higher in brown rice) | High in B-vitamins and selenium |  ---### **Considerations for Replacing Quinoa**  1. **Rice**:     - **White Rice**: A good alternative if youâ€™re looking for a light and easy-to-digest option, but itâ€™s less nutrient-dense than quinoa.     - **Brown Rice**: A better option nutritionally than white rice, as it contains more fiber and minerals.  2. **Wheat**:     - **Whole Wheat**: A fiber-rich option with moderate protein but contains gluten, which may not suit people with gluten intolerance or celiac disease.     - **Bulgur or Cracked Wheat**: A good substitute for quinoa in salads or pilafs, with similar texture and nutrients.  3. **Portion Control**:     - Rice and wheat are higher in carbs compared to quinoa, so watch portions if managing weight or blood sugar.  ---### **When to Choose Each**  - **Quinoa**: Best for a protein-rich, gluten-free option.  - **Rice**: Ideal for a mild flavor or if you prefer gluten-free but donâ€™t need as much protein.  - **Wheat**: Works well for those without gluten issues and looking for a hearty, high-fiber option.  ---### **Tips for Substitution**  - Match portion sizes: Use **1 cup cooked rice/wheat** for **1 cup cooked quinoa**.  - Experiment with **brown rice** or **bulgur** to retain more nutrients.  - Add extra **protein** (e.g., beans, lentils, chicken) if replacing quinoa with rice or wheat to balance the meal.  Let me know if you'd like recipes or meal ideas!"""

default_split_text = default_splitter.split_text(sample_text)
new_split_text = new_splitter.split_text(sample_text)

print(default_split_text[0])
print(new_split_text[0])
```

```markdown
## Output

### split_text[0]
'Yes, you can replace **quinoa** with **rice** or **wheat**, but itâ€™s important to understand the differences between these grains to make an informed choice:  ---### **Quinoa vs. Rice vs. Wheat**  | **Nutrient**          |'

### new_split_text[0]
'Yes, you can replace **quinoa** with **rice** or **wheat**, but itâ€™s important to understand the differences between these grains to make an informed choice:  ---### **Quinoa vs. Rice vs. Wheat**  | **Nutrient**          | **Quinoa**                  | **Rice** (White/Brown)       | **Wheat** (Whole Grain)    |  |------------------------|-----------------------------|-----------------------------|---------------------------|  | **Protein**            | High, contains all 9 essential amino acids | Lower (especially white rice) | Moderate (higher in whole wheat) |  | **Fiber**              | High (especially for digestion) | Low (white rice), Moderate (brown rice) | High'
```


### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable)

_No response_

### Description

I'm trying to use langchain_text_splitters to chunk my documents into chunks of size 256 with 128 overlap recursively using the following function

> RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter.from_huggingface_tokenizer

However I observed that an overwhelming majority of the chunks were nowhere near the 256 tokens length. Upon further digging, I noticed that the default length function being used here was 

> lambda x: len(tokenizer.encode(x))

Using the encode function to count the tokens always counts at least two extra tokens in my case (begin and end tokens for bge-m3) for every word unit present in the text after splitting on separators. This led to the chunks being much smaller than intended, which led to failures in the downstream application. I think replacing the default length function for the huggingface tokenizer by

> lambda x: len(tokenizer.tokenize(x))

solves this problem and also avoids double counting of those special tokens.

I did not find any issues in tiktoken and sentence-transformers tokenizers. Even though they use the encode function as default functions for calculating length, the tiktoken encoder actually takes into account those special tokens and the sentence-transformers lenght function skips the first and last token before counting the number of tokens.

Package Information

author: FT-Fetters
body:

- [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).

### Example Code

```python
ChatOpenAI(
            openai_api_base=os.getenv("OPENAI_API_BASE"),
            model_name=os.getenv("OPENAI_MODEL", "deepseek-32b"),
            temperature=temperature,
            openai_proxy=os.getenv("OPENAI_PROXY", ""),
            request_timeout=120,
            max_tokens=max_tokens
        )
```

### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable)

> File "/Users/xxx/project/python/policy-qa/venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/langchain_core/runnables/base.py", line 3058, in ainvoke
    input = await asyncio.create_task(part(), context=context)  # type: ignore

                 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/Users/xxx/project/python/policy-qa/venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/langchain_openai/chat_models/base.py", line 960, in _agenerate
    response = await self.async_client.create(**payload)
               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/Users/xxx/project/python/policy-qa/venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/openai/resources/chat/completions.py", line 1727, in create
    return await self._post(
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/Users/xxx/project/python/policy-qa/venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/openai/_base_client.py", line 1849, in post
    return await self.request(cast_to, opts, stream=stream, stream_cls=stream_cls)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/Users/xxx/project/python/policy-qa/venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/openai/_base_client.py", line 1543, in request
    return await self._request(
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/Users/xxx/project/python/policy-qa/venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/openai/_base_client.py", line 1644, in _request
    raise self._make_status_error_from_response(err.response) from None
openai.BadRequestError: Error code: 400 - {'object': 'error', 'message': "[{'type': 'extra_forbidden', 'loc': ('body', 'max_completion_tokens'), 'msg': 'Extra inputs are not permitted', 'input': 1}]", 'type': 'BadRequestError', 'param': None, 'code': 400}

### Description


**Issue: Compatibility Problem Between `max_tokens` and `max_completion_tokens`**

I deployed a DeepSeek 32b model using vLLM on the server. However, when I tried to set the `max_tokens` parameter with `ChatOpenAI`, an error occurred, indicating that the `max_completion_tokens` parameter is not supported.

After reviewing the source code, I found the following snippet in `langchain_openai/chat_models/base.py[2001:2014]`:

```python
def _get_request_payload(
    self,
    input_: LanguageModelInput,
    *,
    stop: Optional[List[str]] = None,
    **kwargs: Any,
) -> dict:
    payload = super()._get_request_payload(input_, stop=stop, **kwargs)
    # max_tokens was deprecated in favor of max_completion_tokens
    # in September 2024 release
    if "max_tokens" in payload:
        payload["max_completion_tokens"] = payload.pop("max_tokens")
    return payload
```
In this code, max_tokens is replaced by max_completion_tokens when processing the payload, because max_tokens was deprecated.

I believe this approach is not ideal as it doesnâ€™t handle all cases. I think both parameters should be supported independently. Since Iâ€™m using langchain_openai version 0.3.4, I checked the source code for version 0.3.6 and found the same logic.

Hereâ€™s my proposed solution:
```python
class MyChatOpenAI(ChatOpenAI):

    def _get_request_payload(self, input_: LanguageModelInput, *, stop: Optional[List[str]] = None, **kwargs: Any) -> dict:
        payload = super()._get_request_payload(input_, stop=stop, **kwargs)
        if "max_completion_tokens" in payload:
            payload["max_tokens"] = payload.pop("max_completion_tokens")
        return payload
```

### System Info

Package Information
-------------------
> langchain_core: 0.3.34
> langchain: 0.3.18
> langchain_community: 0.3.17
> langsmith: 0.3.6
> langchain_openai: 0.3.4
> langchain_text_splitters: 0.3.6

This method does seem to solve the problem, but Iâ€™m not sure if there are any functional differences between BaseChatOpenAI and ChatOpenAI.

           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

                            ^^^^^^^^^^^^
AttributeError: module 'openai' has no attribute 'error'
```

### Description

I am trying do embed some documents with LocalAI and pgvector.

This error should not appear. I found some [issues](https://community.openai.com/t/attributeerror-module-openai-has-no-attribute-error/486676) about the same error message from last year, which was solved by downgrading packages.
But those versions are too old, so I don't feel comfortable downgrading them that far.

I am on WSL2 Debian on Windows 11.

EDIT:

Using `openai` directly with the same configuration, I got no problem connecting to my LocalAI instance.

Hi, @wnhrt. I'm [Dosu](https://dosu.dev), and I'm helping the LangChain team manage their backlog. I'm marking this issue as stale.

**Issue Summary:**
- You reported an `AttributeError` related to the 'openai' module missing an 'error' attribute.
- The error occurs when adding documents to a PGVector store.
- The issue persists even after updating to the latest version of LangChain.
- Another user, `yichenTv`, has confirmed experiencing the same issue.

**Next Steps:**
- Please let us know if this issue is still relevant with the latest version of LangChain by commenting here.
- If there is no further activity, this issue will be automatically closed in 7 days.

Thank you for your understanding and contribution!

title: [Docs] Update deprecated Pydantic .schema() method to .model_json_schema() in How to convert Runnables to Tools guide
author: 97tkddnjs
body:
### URL

https://python.langchain.com/docs/how_to/convert_runnable_to_tool/#in-agents

### Checklist

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I included a link to the documentation page I am referring to (if applicable).

### Issue with current documentation:

The documentation at https://python.langchain.com/docs/how_to/convert_runnable_to_tool/#in-agents  contains outdated code examples that use the deprecated Pydantic .schema() method.

It similar issue like this https://github.com/langchain-ai/langchain/issues/31609


## Proposed Solution
Update the documentation to use the new Pydantic V2 method:

##Current (deprecated):
```py
update_favorite_pets.get_input_schema().schema()
```

##Should be updated to:
```py
update_favorite_pets.get_input_schema().model_json_schema()
```

##Suggested Changes
Replace all instances of .schema() with .model_json_schema() in the tool runtime documentation


I'd be happy to submit a PR to fix this

### Idea or request for content:

_No response_

title: feature[anthropic]: dynamically set max_tokens
author: ccurme
body:
### Privileged issue

- [x] I am a LangChain maintainer, or was asked directly by a LangChain maintainer to create an issue here.

### Issue Content

Anthropic's messages API [requires](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages#body-max-tokens) an integer `max_tokens` parameter, which is currently set at 1024 (also the example value in their reference doc for that parameter).

This is a bad fit for Anthropic's more recent models, which may generate reasoning, server-side tool invocations, and other varieties of content and have commensurately higher token limits (64,000 for Claude 3.7 and 4). ctrl+F for "max output" [here](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/about-claude/models/overview) to see limits for each model.

It would be nice to set this attribute to `Optional[int]` and, if None, set the value according to the model's documented maximum.

This is technically a breaking change.

comments.body:
@ccurme  I suggest making max_tokens: `Optional[int]` but defaulting to 1024 if not provided. This keeps the current behavior unchanged and lets users set a higher limit manually when needed.

Example:

```python

if max_tokens is None:
    max_tokens = 1024
```
This avoids any breaking change while adding flexibility.

title: Issue: Error in LangChainTracer.on_chain_error callback: TracerException('No indexed run ID da9518a3-b6ce-4525-a985-10b3ad41fef9.')
author: jorgearaujo
body:
### Checked other resources

- [X] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [X] I searched the LangChain documentation with the integrated search.
- [X] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it.
- [X] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.

### Example Code

```python
prompt_template = ChatPromptTemplate.from_messages(
[
    ("system", prompt),
    ("user", "{input}"),
    MessagesPlaceholder(variable_name="agent_scratchpad"),
])
llm = ChatOpenAI(model = llm)
llm_with_tools = llm.bind_tools(tools)
input = {
        "input": lambda x: x["input"],
        "agent_scratchpad": lambda x: format_to_openai_tool_messages(
            x["intermediate_steps"]
        ),
    }
agent = (
    input
    | prompt_template
    | llm_with_tools
    | OpenAIToolsAgentOutputParser()
)
agent_executor = AgentExecutor(agent=agent, tools=tools, verbose=True)
for chunk in self.agent_executor.stream({"input": input}):
    if "output" in chunk:
        return chunk["output"]
```

### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable)

Error in LangChainTracer.on_chain_error callback: TracerException('No indexed run ID da9518a3-b6ce-4525-a985-10b3ad41fef9.')

### Description

I am trying to trace my LangChain runs by using LangSmith, but I get the following error at the end of the flow:
`Error in LangChainTracer.on_chain_error callback: TracerException('No indexed run ID da9518a3-b6ce-4525-a985-10b3ad41fef9.')`

The environment variable is set up as environment variable using `.env`.

The run is however logged in LangSmith and I can see it, but the error still appears.

title: langchain-google-genai dependency incompatibility with recent colab (google-generativeai 0.8.5 )
author: haniehm
body:
### Checked other resources

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it.
- [x] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.
- [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).
- [x] I posted a self-contained, minimal, reproducible example. A maintainer can copy it and run it AS IS.

### Example Code

The following code on google colab generates a dependency conflict whose error message is captured under the errors:
``` python:
%pip install -U langchain-google-genai 
```

### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable)

ERROR: pip's dependency resolver does not currently take into account all the packages that are installed. This behaviour is the source of the following dependency conflicts.
google-generativeai 0.8.5 requires google-ai-generativelanguage==0.6.15, but you have google-ai-generativelanguage 0.6.18 which is incompatible.

### Description

The above code on google colab generates a dependency conflict whose error message is captured under the errors above.

### System Info

google colab free tier
runtime: python 3
free tier cpu

comments.body:
Langchain is already installed and is at it's newest version in google colab.
`%pip install -U --upgrade langchain-google-genai`

> Langchain is already installed and is at it's newest version in google colab. `%pip install -U --upgrade langchain-google-genai`

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d0e2427a-9265-48b4-a0d5-494e297174f9)

Avoid using google-generativeai, as it is deprecated and causes version conflicts.
For example, google-generativeai==0.8.5 requires google-ai-generativelanguage==0.6.15, but you have google-ai-generativelanguage==0.6.18, which is incompatible.

Just use:

    google-ai-generativelanguage==0.6.18

    langchain-google-genai==2.1.5

You should be fine with these.

### Checked other resources - [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue. - [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it. - [x] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code. - [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package). - [x] I posted a self-contained, minimal, reproducible example. A maintainer can copy it and run it AS IS. ### Example Code ```python from langchain_postgres import PGVector from langchain.indexes import SQLRecordManager, index from langchain_core.documents import Document from langchain_google_genai import GoogleGenerativeAIEmbeddings from urllib.parse import quote_plus # Setup CONNECTION_STRING = f"postgresql+psycopg://{user}:{quote_plus(db_pwd)}@{connection_url}/{database}" embeddings = GoogleGenerativeAIEmbeddings(google_api_key="", model="models/gemini-embedding-exp-03-07") # Create identical documents doc1 = Document( page_content="camp_1", metadata={"ow_id": "1", "id": "11", "start_time": 1742913601, "end_time": None, "dimension_field": "campaign"} ) doc2 = Document( page_content="camp_2", metadata={"ow_id": "1", "id": "22", "start_time": 1742913601, "end_time": 1742913601, "dimension_field": "campaign"} ) # Index into collection A collection_name_a = "a_vs" vector_store_a = PGVector( connection=CONNECTION_STRING, embeddings=embeddings, collection_name=collection_name_a, use_jsonb=True ) record_manager_a = SQLRecordManager(f"postgres/{collection_name_a}", db_url=CONNECTION_STRING) record_manager_a.create_schema() result_a = index( [doc1, doc2], record_manager_a, vector_store_a, cleanup="incremental", source_id_key="ow_id" ) print(f"Collection A indexing result: {result_a}") # Index same documents into collection B collection_name_b = "b_vs" vector_store_b = PGVector( connection=CONNECTION_STRING, embeddings=embeddings, collection_name=collection_name_b, use_jsonb=True ) record_manager_b = SQLRecordManager(f"postgres/{collection_name_b}", db_url=CONNECTION_STRING) record_manager_b.create_schema() result_b = index( [doc1, doc2], record_manager_b, vector_store_b, cleanup="incremental", source_id_key="ow_id" ) print(f"Collection B indexing result: {result_b}") # Check actual document count in vector store langchain_pg_embedding tbl # Expected: 4 documents (2 in each collection) # Actual: Only 2 documents total (data loss!) # >> output # Collection A indexing result: {'num_added': 2, 'num_updated': 0, 'num_skipped': 0, 'num_deleted': 0} # Collection B indexing result: {'num_added': 2, 'num_updated': 0, 'num_skipped': 0, 'num_deleted': 0} ``` ### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable) No error is thrown, but there is data loss visible occurring during the upsertion of Docuements using `index()` or `aindex()` function. **Expected:** 4 documents total (2 in collectionÂ a_vs, 2 in collectionÂ b_vs) **Actual:** Only 2 documents total, both ending up in the same collection **langchain_pg_collection tbl**
**langchain_pg_embedding tbl**
**upsertion_record tbl** ### Description Documents with identical content and metadata were generating the same hash when indexed into different vector store collections, causing cross collection data contamination. This resulted in documents intended for separate collections being stored in the same physical collection. And also record manager shows correct entries, but vector store has missing documents which makes it even more hard to catch. Root cause: TheÂ [_HashedDocument](https://github.com/langchain-ai/langchain/blob/01fcdff118543063faea5652716957160951ce99/libs/core/langchain_core/indexing/api.py#L55)Â hash calculation only considered document content and metadata, but not the collection context. This meant thatÂ `Document(page_content="text", metadata={"id": "1"})`Â would get identical hashes whether indexed into "collection_a" or "collection_b". ### System Info System Information ------------------ > OS: Darwin > OS Version: Darwin Kernel Version 24.3.0: Thu Jan 2 20:24:06 PST 2025; root:xnu-11215.81.4~3/RELEASE_ARM64_T8103 > Python Version: 3.12.11 | packaged by Anaconda, Inc. | (main, Jun 5 2025, 08:06:15) [Clang 14.0.6 ] Package Information ------------------- > langchain_core: 0.3.65 > langchain: 0.3.25 > langchain_community: 0.3.25 > langsmith: 0.3.45 > langchain_google_genai: 2.1.5 > langchain_postgres: 0.0.14 > langchain_text_splitters: 0.3.8 > langgraph_sdk: 0.1.70 Optional packages not installed ------------------------------- > langserve Other Dependencies ------------------ > aiohttp<4.0.0,>=3.8.3: Installed. No version info available. > async-timeout<5.0.0,>=4.0.0;: Installed. No version info available. > asyncpg: 0.30.0 > dataclasses-json<0.7,>=0.5.7: Installed. No version info available. > filetype: 1.2.0 > google-ai-generativelanguage: 0.6.18 > httpx: 0.28.1 > httpx-sse<1.0.0,>=0.4.0: Installed. No version info available. > httpx>=0.25.2: Installed. title: Implement langchain-xinference
author: ccurme
body:
### Privileged issue

- [x] I am a LangChain maintainer, or was asked directly by a LangChain maintainer to create an issue here.

### Issue Content

Implement a standalone package for Xinference chat models and other abstractions following the contributing guide [here](https://python.langchain.com/docs/contributing/how_to/integrations/).

This would allow us to properly version the package, manage the `xinference` dependency, and properly integration test the models.

title: `AttributeError("'dict' object has no attribute 'model_dump'")` with openai built-in web search when using LangGraph with `stream_mode=["debug", "messages"]`
author: PE51K
body:
### Checked other resources

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it.
- [x] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.
- [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).
- [x] I posted a self-contained, minimal, reproducible example. A maintainer can copy it and run it AS IS.

### Example Code

```python
import asyncio

from langchain_openai import ChatOpenAI
from langgraph.prebuilt import create_react_agent


llm: ChatOpenAI = ChatOpenAI(
    api_key="",
    model="gpt-4.1",
    use_responses_api=True,
)

tools = [
    {"type": "web_search_preview"},
]

chatbot = create_react_agent(
    model=llm,
    tools=tools,
)


async def main():
    async for chunk in chatbot.astream({"messages": [("user", "read https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banana")]}, stream_mode=["debug", "messages"]):
        print(chunk)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())
```

```

### Description

I'm using langchain-openai and LangGraph to implement simple chatbot with tool results logging and text streaming.

I expect to see separate chunks from both streaming modes, but facing AttributeError. 

It's interesting tho, that using only one option for `stream_mode`, like `="debug"` or `stream_mode="messages"` works as expected.

comments.body: This bug report is really clear and well put together. The detailed description, easy-to-follow example, and exact stack trace are super helpful for troubleshooting, especially the note about the failure with stream_mode=[debug, messages]. This AttributeError shows there's a problem with data types in the streaming pipeline of langchain_openai, which affects how LangGraph works.

This issue has been fixed in `langchain_openai` version **0.3.23**.   [https://github.com/langchain-ai/langchain/pull/31597](https://github.com/langchain-ai/langchain/pull/31597)
The cause was a breaking change introduced in the `openai` package starting from version **1.82.0**.  
If you're using an OpenAI version earlier than 1.82.0, you shouldn't encounter this issue.

### Context

Up to version 1.81.x, the response object looked like this:

```python
ResponseTextAnnotationDeltaEvent(
    annotation=AnnotationURLCitation(
        end_index=1427,
        start_index=1351,
        title='Banana',
        type='url_citation',
        url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banana?utm_source=openai'
    ),
    annotation_index=2,
    content_index=0,
    item_id='msg_684d15d114ac819984a1c97a417b78f206ace89068628a1e',
    output_index=1,
    type='response.output_text.annotation.added',
    sequence_number=264
)
```
Starting from version 1.82.0, it changed to:

```python
ResponseAudioDeltaEvent(
    delta=None,
    sequence_number=366,
    type='response.output_text.annotation.added',
    item_id='msg_684d167f3808819a82577a97f1edb50c094b746ed4964905',
    output_index=1,
    content_index=0,
    annotation_index=5,
    annotation={
        'type': 'url_citation',
        'end_index': 2094,
        'start_index': 2018,
        'title': 'Banana',
        'url': 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banana?utm_source=openai'
    }
)
```

The annotation field was changed from a typed object (AnnotationURLCitation) to a plain dictionary in version 1.82.0, which caused the compatibility issue.

title: bug[core]: fix tool descriptions when BaseModels have no docstring
author: ccurme
body:
### Privileged issue

- [x] I am a LangChain maintainer, or was asked directly by a LangChain maintainer to create an issue here.

### Issue Content

When Pydantic models are cast to BaseTool and are missing a docstring, we use the docstring for BaseModel itself:

```python
from langchain_core.tools import tool
from pydantic import BaseModel


@tool
class MyTool(BaseModel):
    foo: str


MyTool.description
```
> '!!! abstract "Usage Documentation"\n    [Models](../concepts/models.md)\n\nA base class for creating Pydantic models.\n\nAttributes:\n    __class_vars__: The names of the class variables defined on the model.\n    __private_attributes__: Metadata about...'

We should use an empty string in this case.

comments.body: @ccurme patched

title: Structured Output .with_structured_output() causes tool_choice 422 error with Azure-hosted Deepseek V3
author: finboard-dev
body:
### Checked other resources

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it.
- [x] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.
- [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).
- [x] I posted a self-contained, minimal, reproducible example. A maintainer can copy it and run it AS IS.

### Example Code

```python
from langchain_core.messages import BaseMessage
from langchain_core.runnables import RunnableConfig
from langgraph.checkpoint.memory import MemorySaver
from langgraph.func import entrypoint
from langgraph.graph import add_messages
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field
from langchain_deepseek import ChatDeepSeek

class ChatbotOutput(BaseModel):
    message: str = Field(description="The message to be sent to the user")

def get_model() -> ModelT:
    return ChatDeepSeek(
            model=<deployment_name>, #change it to your model name
            temperature=0.5,
            streaming=False,
            api_base=<azure_deepseek_endpoint>, #change it to your api url
            max_tokens=None,
            timeout=None,
            max_retries=2,
            api_key=<azure_deepseek_key>  #change it to your api key
        )

@entrypoint(checkpointer=MemorySaver())
async def chatbot(
    inputs: dict[str, list[BaseMessage]],
    *,
    previous: dict[str, list[BaseMessage]],
    config: RunnableConfig,
):
    messages = inputs["messages"]
    if previous:
        messages = add_messages(previous["messages"], messages)

    model = get_model('azure-deepseek-chat').with_structured_output(ChatbotOutput)
    response = await model.ainvoke(messages)
    return entrypoint.final(
        value={"messages": [response.message]}, save={"messages": add_messages(messages, response.message)}
    )
```

```
from langchain_openai import ChatOpenAI
import asyncio
import os
from fastapi import HTTPException
@app.get("/test")
async def test_openai_streaming():
    # Retrieve API key from environment variable
    openai_api_key = 'xxx'
    
    # Validate API key
    if not openai_api_key:
        raise HTTPException(status_code=400, detail="OpenAI API key is not configured")
    
    try:
        # Initialize ChatOpenAI with API key
        chat = ChatOpenAI(
            model="gpt-4o-mini", 
            temperature=0,
            api_key=openai_api_key,  # Explicitly pass the API key
            streaming=True  # Ensure streaming is enabled
        )
        
        # Collect chunks to return
        chunks = []
        
        # Stream the response
        async for chunk in chat.astream("Hello, how are you?"):
            chunks.append(chunk.content)
            print(chunk.content, end='', flush=True)
        
        # Return the full response
        return {"response": ''.join(chunks)}
    
    except Exception as e:
        # More detailed error handling
        print(f"Streaming error: {e}")
        raise HTTPException(status_code=500, detail=f"OpenAI streaming error: {str(e)}")

body:
### Checked other resources

### Example Code

```python
retrievers=[]
self.prompt = PROD_ANALYSIS_SYSTEM_PROMPT if custom_prompt == '' else custom_prompt + "{context}"
common_space_index = ["csp-facets-prod-analysis", "csp-macess", "cns-resource-center"]
for index in common_space_index:
            k=100
            self.index_name = index
            if index == "csp-macess":
                self.vector_store = AzureSearch(azure_search_endpoint=os.getenv("AZURE_SEARCH_SERVICE_NAME"), azure_search_key=os.getenv("AZURE_SEARCH_ADMIN_KEY"), index_name=self.index_name, embedding_function=self.embeddings.embed_query, semantic_configuration_name="my-semantic-config")
                retriever = self.vector_store.as_retriever(search_type="semantic_hybrid",
                    k=k,
                    semantic_configuration_name="my-semantic-config",
                )
            else:
                self.vector_store = AzureSearch(azure_search_endpoint=os.getenv("AZURE_SEARCH_SERVICE_NAME"), azure_search_key=os.getenv("AZURE_SEARCH_ADMIN_KEY"), index_name=self.index_name, embedding_function=self.embeddings.embed_query)
                retriever = self.vector_store.as_retriever(search_type="similarity_score_threshold",
                    k=k,
                    search_kwargs={'score_threshold': 0.83}
                )
            retrievers.append(retriever)
retriever = EnsembleRetriever(retrievers=retrievers, weights=[1/len(retrievers)]*len(retrievers))
qa_prompt = ChatPromptTemplate.from_messages(
            [
                ("system", self.prompt), MessagesPlaceholder("chat_history"), ("human", "{input}"),
            ]
        )
question_answer_chain = create_stuff_documents_chain(self.llm, qa_prompt) 
rag_chain = create_retrieval_chain(
            retriever,
            question_answer_chain
        )
result = rag_chain.invoke({"input":question, "chat_history":chat_history})
```

### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable)

float() argument must be a string or a real number, not 'NoneType'

### Description

Currently, I'm running into this float error when I use the semantic search retriever. If I remove the semantic search retriever and only use the similarity_score_threshold retrievers, I do not run into this error. I'm having a hard time understanding where this error is coming from and how to resolve it.

Edit: I have discovered that the float error is not there when I set k = 50. I'm not entirely sure why it works when k is lowered but it seems to be working now.

title: Stream does not work when using ChatXAI with AgentExecutor
author: kboniadi
body:
### Checked other resources

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I searched the LangChain documentation with the integrated search.
- [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it.
- [x] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.
- [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).

### Example Code

```python
import os

from langchain.agents import (AgentExecutor, create_tool_calling_agent)
from langchain_core.chat_history import InMemoryChatMessageHistory
from langchain_core.prompts import ChatPromptTemplate, MessagesPlaceholder
from langchain_core.runnables.history import RunnableWithMessageHistory
from langchain_core.tools import tool
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field
from langchain_xai import ChatXAI

prompt2 = f"""You are a very smart AI Bot"""
    
# create a client and stream out the results from a basic template
llm = ChatXAI(
    model="grok",
    api_key="...",
    max_tokens=4096,
    top_p=0.95,
    streaming=True,
    max_retries=3,
)

prompt = ChatPromptTemplate.from_messages(
    [
        ("system", prompt2),
        # First put the history
        MessagesPlaceholder(variable_name="chat_history"),
        # Then the new input
        ("human", "{input}"),
        # Finally the scratchpad
        MessagesPlaceholder(variable_name="agent_scratchpad"),
    ]
)
    
@tool
def magic_function(input: int) -> int:
    """Applies a magic function to an input."""
    return input + 2

tools = [
    magic_function
]

        
agent = create_tool_calling_agent(llm, tools, prompt)
agent_executor = AgentExecutor(
    agent=agent,
    tools=tools,
)

memory = InMemoryChatMessageHistory(session_id="test-session")
agent_with_chat_history = RunnableWithMessageHistory(
    agent_executor,
    # This is needed because in most real world scenarios, a session id is needed
    # It isn't really used here because we are using a simple in memory ChatMessageHistory
    lambda session_id: memory,
    input_messages_key="input",
    history_messages_key="chat_history",
)


res = []
for response in agent_with_chat_history.stream({"input": "What is 7+11?<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>"}, {'configurable': {'session_id': 'test-session'}}):
    print(response)
```

### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable)

no errors

### Description

I'm trying to stream a response back using ChatXAI and AgentExecutor.
I expect to see data streamed back byte by byte
I instead see the full response returned just like the `invoke` method

title: get_num_tokens_from_messages implicitly requires transformers
author: g-pavlov
body:
### Checked other resources

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I searched the LangChain documentation with the integrated search.
- [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it.
- [x] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.
- [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).

### Example Code

Consider the following code
```
model = init_chat_model(
        "anthropic.claude-3-5-sonnet-20240620-v1:0",
        model_provider="aws_bedrock", 
        temperature=0
    )
model.get_num_tokens_from_messages(messages)
```

### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable)

```
  File "sample.py", line 74, in sample_func
    token_count = model.get_num_tokens_from_messages(messages)
                  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/langchain_core/language_models/base.py", line 393, in get_num_tokens_from_messages
    return sum(self.get_num_tokens(get_buffer_string([m])) for m in messages)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/langchain_core/language_models/base.py", line 393, in <genexpr>
    return sum(self.get_num_tokens(get_buffer_string([m])) for m in messages)
               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/langchain_core/language_models/base.py", line 366, in get_num_tokens
    return len(self.get_token_ids(text))
               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/langchain_core/language_models/base.py", line 353, in get_token_ids
    return _get_token_ids_default_method(text)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/langchain_core/language_models/base.py", line 77, in _get_token_ids_default_method
    tokenizer = get_tokenizer()
                ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/langchain_core/language_models/base.py", line 69, in get_tokenizer
    raise ImportError(msg) from e
ImportError: Could not import transformers python package. This is needed in order to calculate get_token_ids. Please install it with `pip install transformers`.
```

### Description

The code implicitly yields import of the transformers library. 

Unfortunately this is not a defined dependency of langchain and neither it is documented as required and when.

Since this is yet another model function it makes sense to treat it a hard dependency and require it to be automatically installed with the langchain itself.
Or alternatively a lightweight fallback could be implemented with the documented option to install the full transformers library.

title: DOC: Exceptions that can be raised by the invocation of LLM models are not described
author: Mark531
body:
### URL

https://python.langchain.com/api_reference/core/language_models/langchain_core.language_models.llms.BaseLLM.html

### Checklist

- [X] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [X] I included a link to the documentation page I am referring to (if applicable).

### Issue with current documentation:

The invoke() or ainvoke() methods of BaseLLMs may raise exceptions, yet the latter are not described in a "**Raises**" section. Some specific implementations like OpenAI's models should have their own exceptions documented too (like RateLimitError I guess).

The problem is that it's currently difficult to write a code that properly handles all possible exceptions without knowing them.

### Idea or request for content:

On top on the "Return type" section, a "Raises" section should be added for invoke() and ainvoke() and maybe other methods.

title: Documentation says you can instantiate Milvus with a db file. But you cannot
author: paperview
body:
### Checked other resources

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it.
- [x] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.
- [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).
- [x] I posted a self-contained, minimal, reproducible example. A maintainer can copy it and run it AS IS.

### Example Code

# Connect to Milvus Lite
URI = "./milvus_example.db"
vector_store = Milvus(
    embedding_function=embeddings,
    connection_args={"uri": URI},
)


### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable)

                logger.error("Invalid Milvus URI: %s", uri)
                raise ValueError("Invalid Milvus URI: %s", uri)

see here https://python.langchain.com/api_reference/_modules/langchain_community/vectorstores/milvus.html

### Description

I want to use a local db file for a vectorstore, but see no way to do so.  

### System Info

python 3.13. MacOS

comments.body:
Please do the following:
```python
from langchain_milvus import Milvus
from langchain_openai import OpenAIEmbeddings

embeddings = OpenAIEmbeddings()

URI = "./milvus_example.db"

vector_store = Milvus(
    embedding_function=embeddings,
    connection_args={"uri": URI},
    index_params={"index_type": "FLAT", "metric_type": "L2"},
)
```

Thanks, can I not use different embeddings with the db file approach? For instance HuggingFaceEmbeddings(model_name="all-mpnet-base-v2")

Below throws the error, for instance:

```
embedding_model = HuggingFaceEmbeddings(model_name="all-mpnet-base-v2")
client = Milvus(
  embedding_function=embedding_model,
  connection_args={"uri": "./milvus_example.db"},
  index_params={"index_type": "FLAT", "metric_type": "L2"},
)

```

FYI to anyone with the same problem I got this working in an isolated test by importing the embeddings properly from langchain, before I was importing from pymilvus. it still isnt working in my flask worker but must be a separate issue. thanks for the response.

title: ChatAnthropic doesn't work for using OpenRouter as base url
author: jiwonmik
body:
### Checked other resources

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it.
- [x] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.
- [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).
- [x] I posted a self-contained, minimal, reproducible example. A maintainer can copy it and run it AS IS.

### Example Code

The following code:

```python
llm = ChatAnthropic(
        model="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219",
        temperature=0,
        max_tokens=1024,
        timeout=None,
        max_retries=2,
        api_key={api_key},
        base_url="https://openrouter.ai/api",
    )
    response = llm.invoke("hello..?")
```

is not working, it throws 405 error.

### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable)

```
2025-05-22 14:14:56,852 | /httpx/_client.py:_send_single_request:1027 | INFO: HTTP Request: POST https://openrouter.ai/api/v1/v1/messages "HTTP/1.1 405 Method Not Allowed"

  File "/{path}env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/langchain_core/language_models/chat_models.py", line 683, in generate
    self._generate_with_cache(
  File "/{path}env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/langchain_core/language_models/chat_models.py", line 908, in _generate_with_cache

  File "/{path}env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/langchain_anthropic/chat_models.py", line 849, in _generate

  File "/{path}env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/anthropic/_utils/_utils.py", line 275, in wrapper

    return self._post(
  File "/{path}env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/anthropic/_base_client.py", line 1330, in post
    return cast(ResponseT, self.request(cast_to, opts, stream=stream, stream_cls=stream_cls))
  File "/{path}env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/anthropic/_base_client.py", line 1007, in request

### Description

I can see that it's requesting to `https://openrouter.ai/api/v1/v1/messages` if you see in the error log below line.
```
2025-05-22 14:14:56,852 | /httpx/_client.py:_send_single_request:1027 | INFO: HTTP Request: POST https://openrouter.ai/api/v1/messages "HTTP/1.1 405 Method Not Allowed"

`https://openrouter.ai/api/v1/messages` seems not valid url, that it should be `https://openrouter.ai/api/v1/chat/completions`.

comments.body:
Hi @jiwonmik,

the 405 error occurs because `chatanthropic` is designed for Anthropic's official api (`https://api.anthropic.com/v1/messages`), but you're using openrouter's API, which expects requests at `/api/v1/chat/completions`. The double `/v1/v1/` in the logged URL (`https://openrouter.ai/api/v1/v1/messages`) suggests a potential URL construction issue, but the core problem is endpoint incompatibility.

To fix this, u should use `ChatOpenRouter` from `langchain_community.chat_models`, which is built for OpenRouter's API. Here's the corrected code:

```python
from langchain_community.chat_models import ChatOpenRouter

llm = ChatOpenRouter(
    model_name="anthropic/claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219",
    temperature=0,
    max_tokens=1024,
    timeout=None,
    max_retries=2,
    openrouter_api_key="your-api-key-here",  # Replace with your OpenRouter API key
)

response = llm.invoke("hello..?")
print(response)

@byteakp Hmm,, is that `ChatOpenRouter` class existing one?

FYI I found [this](https://github.com/langchain-ai/langchain/discussions/27964), will try with this one.

> [@byteakp](https://github.com/byteakp) Hmm,, is that `ChatOpenRouter` class existing one?
> 
> FYI I found [this](https://github.com/langchain-ai/langchain/discussions/27964), will try with this one.

Yes, that ChatOpenRouter class isnâ€™t part of the official LangChain repo â€” itâ€™s a custom workaround shared in the GitHub discussion [#27964](https://github.com/langchain-ai/langchain/issues/27964). It subclasses ChatOpenAI and overrides the base_url and API key handling to work with OpenRouter.

If youâ€™re integrating OpenRouter into a LangGraph project or want to use tools, this workaround should definitely help!

title: `ChatPromptValue.to_string()` outputs stringified raw content structure instead of extracted text
author: mshavliuk
body:
### Checked other resources

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it.
- [x] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.
- [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).
- [x] I posted a self-contained, minimal, reproducible example. A maintainer can copy it and run it AS IS.

### Example Code

Simplest demo:

```python
from langchain_core.messages import HumanMessage
from langchain_core.prompt_values import ChatPromptValue

human_message = HumanMessage(content=[{"type": "text", "text": "Hello, world!"}])

print(human_message.text())

prompt = ChatPromptValue(messages=[human_message])

print(prompt.to_string())
```


### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable)

The output:
```
Hello, world!
Human: [{'type': 'text', 'text': 'Hello, world!'}]
```

### Description

`ChatPromptValue.to_string()` passes its messages to `get_buffer_string`. Based on the `get_buffer_string` definition and docstring I expected it to be compatible with `BaseMessage.content: Union[str, list[Union[str, dict]]]` structure and include only the text content of the given messages (as it's done in `BaseMessage.text()` method), so for the provided code the output would be `"Human: Hello, world!"`



### System Info

```
System Information
------------------
> OS:  Darwin
> OS Version:  Darwin Kernel Version 24.5.0: Tue Apr 22 19:54:43 PDT 2025; root:xnu-11417.121.6~2/RELEASE_ARM64_T8132
> Python Version:  3.12.8 (main, Jan 27 2025, 11:56:06) [Clang 16.0.0 (clang-1600.0.26.6)]

Package Information
-------------------
> langchain_core: 0.3.65
> langchain: 0.3.25
```

title: DOC: Inconsistent import path for create_retrieval_chain between API docs and examples
author: asherk7
body:
### URL

https://python.langchain.com/api_reference/langchain/chains/langchain.chains.retrieval.create_retrieval_chain.html

### Checklist

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I included a link to the documentation page I am referring to (if applicable).

### Issue with current documentation:

I noticed a discrepancy between the API reference and the code examples for `create_retrieval_chain`.

The [API documentation](https://python.langchain.com/api_reference/langchain/chains/langchain.chains.retrieval.create_retrieval_chain.html) states that the import path is ```from langchain.chains.retrieval import create_retrieval_chain```, but most tutorials and examples in the documentation use ```from langchain.chains import create_retrieval_chain```.

### Idea or request for content:

Some users (myself included) have encountered an 'ImportError' with the latter. Additionally, when using IDE extensions to view an API's functionality, the description appears blank rather than a detailed explanation.

Some examples of the latter import:
https://python.langchain.com/docs/versions/migrating_chains/retrieval_qa/ 
https://python.langchain.com/v0.2/docs/tutorials/rag/

This might be a versioning issue or a matter of re-export behaviour. Would it be helpful to update the docs or clarify which import path should be used going forward?

comments.body: Can you post the error, because I have verified from the repository the imports should work.

The error was fixed, there was an issue in my virtual environment, and I had to recreate it and reinstall Langchain. The error message was "cannot import name 'create_retrieval_chain' from 'langchain.chains'. 

Apologies for the confusion.

On this topic, though, I noticed some documentation examples use 'from langchain.chains' while the API documentation uses 'from langchain.chains.retrieval'.

Would it make sense to standardize the import path across examples and the reference docs? Even if both are valid, aligning them could help avoid confusion for new Langchain users (like me), and for IDE extensions.

Example on VSCode using Pylance:
langchain.chains:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9ad67706-5ad3-45cf-96a3-8228088c5903)

langchain.chains.retrieval:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e824816c-2855-40b1-8e38-14d548b7b2ca)

I'd be happy to contribute to these if it's useful, otherwise, thanks for the reply.

title: AIMessageChunk init_tool_calls failed, when the chunk args is None
author: run-zhi
body:
### Checked other resources

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I searched the LangChain documentation with the integrated search.
- [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it.
- [x] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.
- [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).

### Example Code

  I'm locally deploying the qwq-32B model using vllm. When running the langgraph_supervisor example, I encountered a problem. When I use the `stream`(`strem_mode="messages"`) function to output content, the tool call fails. After tracing the code, I found that the tool_call arguments returned by the LLM is None. However, in the `init_tool_calls` function of the AIMessageChunk class in `langchain_core/messages/ai.py`, there is no check for the case where args is equal to None, which leads to an error when calling `parse_partial_json`.

### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable)

My test example code:

```python
for event in app.stream({
    "messages": [
        {
            "role": "user",
            "content": "what's the combined headcount of the FAANG companies in 2024?"
        }
    ]
},
stream_mode="messages"):
    print(event)
```

code run output:
```shell
....
(AIMessageChunk(content='\n\n', additional_kwargs={}, response_metadata={}, id='run-b94df66e-76d8-4281-9ba8-679e7b5a0868'), {'langgraph_step': 1, 'langgraph_node': 'agent', 'langgraph_triggers': ('start:agent',), 'langgraph_path': ('__pregel_pull', 'agent'), 'langgraph_checkpoint_ns': 'supervisor:6925c4dd-d95f-42c5-ed48-27f85a5b9fda|agent:df014e53-85d6-9661-899c-df412d8e6ace', 'checkpoint_ns': 'supervisor:6925c4dd-d95f-42c5-ed48-27f85a5b9fda', 'ls_provider': 'openai', 'ls_model_name': 'qwq-32b', 'ls_model_type': 'chat', 'ls_temperature': 0.0})
(AIMessageChunk(content='', additional_kwargs={'tool_calls': [{'index': 0, 'id': 'chatcmpl-tool-aa8886dc40bc4cf4941818e667e102e6', 'function': {'arguments': None, 'name': 'transfer_to_research_expert'}, 'type': 'function'}]}, response_metadata={}, id='run-b94df66e-76d8-4281-9ba8-679e7b5a0868', invalid_tool_calls=[{'name': 'transfer_to_research_expert', 'args': None, 'id': 'chatcmpl-tool-aa8886dc40bc4cf4941818e667e102e6', 'error': None, 'type': 'invalid_tool_call'}], tool_call_chunks=[{'name': 'transfer_to_research_expert', 'args': None, 'id': 'chatcmpl-tool-aa8886dc40bc4cf4941818e667e102e6', 'index': 0, 'type': 'tool_call_chunk'}]), {'langgraph_step': 1, 'langgraph_node': 'agent', 'langgraph_triggers': ('start:agent',), 'langgraph_path': ('__pregel_pull', 'agent'), 'langgraph_checkpoint_ns': 'supervisor:6925c4dd-d95f-42c5-ed48-27f85a5b9fda|agent:df014e53-85d6-9661-899c-df412d8e6ace', 'checkpoint_ns': 'supervisor:6925c4dd-d95f-42c5-ed48-27f85a5b9fda', 'ls_provider': 'openai', 'ls_model_name': 'qwq-32b', 'ls_model_type': 'chat', 'ls_temperature': 0.0})
(AIMessageChunk(content='', additional_kwargs={}, response_metadata={'finish_reason': 'tool_calls', 'model_name': 'qwq-32b'}, id='run-b94df66e-76d8-4281-9ba8-679e7b5a0868'), {'langgraph_step': 1, 'langgraph_node': 'agent', 'langgraph_triggers': ('start:agent',), 'langgraph_path': ('__pregel_pull', 'agent'), 'langgraph_checkpoint_ns': 'supervisor:6925c4dd-d95f-42c5-ed48-27f85a5b9fda|agent:df014e53-85d6-9661-899c-df412d8e6ace', 'checkpoint_ns': 'supervisor:6925c4dd-d95f-42c5-ed48-27f85a5b9fda', 'ls_provider': 'openai', 'ls_model_name': 'qwq-32b', 'ls_model_type': 'chat', 'ls_temperature': 0.0})
```

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3b526887-8c45-4c4e-9bbc-9a2eb8e606ae)
We can see that the function arguments in the above output is None.

The code in `langchain_core/messages/ai.py`:

```python
class AIMessageChunk(AIMessage, BaseMessageChunk):
...
    @model_validator(mode="after")
    def init_tool_calls(self) -> Self:
        ...
        for chunk in self.tool_call_chunks:
            try:
                args_ = parse_partial_json(chunk["args"]) if chunk["args"] != "" else {}  # type: ignore[arg-type]
            ...
            except Exception:
                add_chunk_to_invalid_tool_calls(chunk)
```
When `chunk["args"]` is None, the `parse_partial_json` function raises an exception, causing the call flow to be interrupted.

### Description

 I'm locally deploying the qwq-32B model using vllm. When running the langgraph_supervisor example, I encountered a problem. When I use the `stream`(`strem_mode="messages"`) function to output content, the tool call fails. After tracing the code, I found that the tool_call arguments returned by the LLM is None. However, in the `init_tool_calls` function of the AIMessageChunk class in `langchain_core/messages/ai.py`, there is no check for the case where args is equal to None, which leads to an error when calling `parse_partial_json`.

### System Info

dependencies = [
    "beautifulsoup4>=4.13.3",
    "langchain-community>=0.3.19",
    "langchain-weaviate>=0.0.4",
    "langchain[openai]>=0.3.20",
    "langgraph>=0.3.15",
    "langgraph-supervisor>=0.0.14",
    "pypdf>=5.4.0",
    "weaviate-client>=4.11.1",
    "xinference-client>=1.3.1.post1",
]

comments.body: @run-zhi how did you fix that?
@run-zhi I encountered a similar issue when using the Qwen3-32B model for tool_calls with no args function. How did you resolve it?

> [@run-zhi](https://github.com/run-zhi) how did you fix that?

just upgrade langgraph version

title: Using LangChain to call the local DeepSeek distillation version of the model output is incomplete
author: ace-xc
body:
### Checked other resources

- [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [x] I searched the LangChain documentation with the integrated search.
- [x] I used the GitHub search to find a similar question and didn't find it.
- [x] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.
- [x] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).

### Example Code

**Observed differences**
(1) Format and structure:
LangChain output:
The beginning directly states that the concept of â€œplace valueâ€ is used to split the number.
A step-by-step explanation of each digit (digit, decile, percentile) is presented for each number.
In the comparison process, the deciles are compared directly, conclusions are drawn, and the final answer is labeled with mathematical symbols and boxes.
OpenAI calls the output directly:
Use the <think> tag to wrap the initial thought process.
Align decimal places by rewriting 9.8 as 9.80, then compare percentiles.
The formatting and language are slightly different, although the final conclusion is the same.
(2) Details of the thinking process:
Both explain why comparing deciles is straightforward, but with different emphases: LangChain emphasizes the notion of â€œplace value,â€ while OpenAI's direct call focuses more on number alignment (e.g., writing 9.8 as 9.80).

The specific version and test sample code results are as followsï¼š
```
Name: langchain
Version: 0.3.18
Summary: Building applications with LLMs through composability
License: MIT
Requires: aiohttp, langchain-core, langchain-text-splitters, langsmith, numpy, pydantic, PyYAML, requests, SQLAlchemy, tenacity
Required-by: langchain-community
Note: you may need to restart the kernel to use updated packages.
```

(1) Original OpenAI API result:

```python
from openai import OpenAI

openai_api_key = "EMPTY"
openai_api_base = "http://0.0.0.0:8888/v1"

client = OpenAI(
    api_key=openai_api_key,
    base_url=openai_api_base,
)

chat_response = client.chat.completions.create(
    model="DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-32B", 
    messages=[
        {"role": "user", "content": "Which is bigger, 9.11 or 9.8?"},
    ],
    temperature=0.000001,
    max_tokens=8192,
    extra_body={
        "repetition_penalty": 1.05,
    },
)
print(chat_response.choices[0].message.content)

```
**output:**
```python
<think>
First, I need to compare the two numbers: 9.11 and 9.8.

Both numbers have the same whole number part, which is 9.

Next, I'll look at the decimal parts. The first number has 0.11, and the second number has 0.8.

To make it easier, I can rewrite 9.8 as 9.80 so that both numbers have the same number of decimal places.

Now, comparing the hundredths place: 0.11 is less than 0.80.

Therefore, 9.11 is less than 9.8.
</think>

To determine which number is larger between **9.11** and **9.8**, let's compare them step by step.

### Step 1: Compare the Whole Number Part
Both numbers have the same whole number part:
- **9**.11
- **9**.8

Since the whole numbers are equal, we move on to compare the decimal parts.

### Step 2: Compare the Decimal Parts
- **9.11** has a decimal part of **0.11**
- **9.8** can be written as **9.80** to have the same number of decimal places.

Now, compare the hundredths place:
- **0.11** (from 9.11)
- **0.80** (from 9.8)

Since **0.11 < 0.80**, it follows that **9.11 < 9.8**.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{9.8 \text{ is bigger}}
\]
```
(2) Langchain Openai API result:
```python
from langchain.llms import OpenAI

llm = OpenAI(
    model_name = "DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-32B",
    openai_api_base = "http://0.0.0.0:8888/v1",
    openai_api_key = "EMPTY",
    temperature=0.000001,
    max_tokens=8192,
)

query = "Which is bigger, 9.11 or 9.8?"
print(llm.invoke(query))
```
**output:**
```python
To figure this out, you can use the concept of place value. Let's break down each number into its place values. For 9.11, the 9 is in the ones place, the 1 is in the tenths place, and the second 1 is in the hundredths place. For 9.8, the 9 is in the ones place, the 8 is in the tenths place, and there is no hundredths place. Now, compare the tenths place of both numbers. Since 8 is greater than 1, 9.8 is bigger than 9.11. So, 9.8 is bigger.

</think>

To determine which number is larger between **9.11** and **9.8**, we can compare them by examining their place values.

### Breaking Down the Numbers:
1. **9.11**
   - **9** is in the **ones place**.
   - **1** is in the **tenths place**.
   - **1** is in the **hundredths place**.

2. **9.8**
   - **9** is in the **ones place**.
   - **8** is in the **tenths place**.
   - There is no **hundredths place** (implied to be **0**).

### Comparing the Numbers:
- **Ones Place:** Both numbers have **9** in the ones place, so they are equal here.
- **Tenths Place:** 
  - **9.11** has **1** in the tenths place.
  - **9.8** has **8** in the tenths place.
  
  Since **8 > 1**, **9.8** is greater than **9.11** in the tenths place.

### Conclusion:
Since **9.8** has a greater value in the tenths place compared to **9.11**, **9.8** is the larger number.

\[
\boxed{9.8}
\]
```
**Conclusion**
The model's output is missing the leading <think> tag. There may be differences in the results under different invocation methods and perhaps in the results. Users may have questions about the details of the interpretation and the format of the output, affecting the understanding of the answer,.

### Error Message and Stack Trace (if applicable)

_No response_

### Description

In the example comparing two numbers (9.11 and 9.8), the answers obtained by calling the OpenAI interface directly versus calling it through LangChain are consistent in their final conclusions (both indicate that 9.8 is larger than 9.11), but there are significant differences in their chain-of-thought processes and formats.

> ### Example Code
> **Observed differences** (1) Format and structure: LangChain output: The beginning directly states that the concept of â€œplace valueâ€ is used to split the number. A step-by-step explanation of each digit (digit, decile, percentile) is presented for each number. In the comparison process, the deciles are compared directly, conclusions are drawn, and the final answer is labeled with mathematical symbols and boxes. OpenAI calls the output directly: Use the tag to wrap the initial thought process. Align decimal places by rewriting 9.8 as 9.80, then compare percentiles. The formatting and language are slightly different, although the final conclusion is the same. (2) Details of the thinking process: Both explain why comparing deciles is straightforward, but with different emphases: LangChain emphasizes the notion of â€œplace value,â€ while OpenAI's direct call focuses more on number alignment (e.g., writing 9.8 as 9.80).
>

> - **0.80** (from 9.8)

> Since **0.11 < 0.80**, it follows that **9.11 < 9.8**.

For 9.11, the 9 is in the ones place, the 1 is in the tenths place, and the second 1 is in the hundredths place. So, 9.8 is bigger.
> 
> </think>

> 1. **9.11**

Hi, boy, the biggest problem here is that these are two different interfaces, /chat/completions and /completions. If you don't know the difference between these two interfaces, please refer to the openai documentation. Also, some parameters of ollama are not supported, but you are using OpenAI here.

Hi, @ace-xc. I'm [Dosu](https://dosu.dev), and I'm helping the LangChain team manage their backlog. I'm marking this issue as stale.

**Issue Summary:**
- Discrepancies in output format when using LangChain with a local DeepSeek distillation model versus direct OpenAI API calls.
- LangChain output emphasizes "place value" and uses mathematical symbols; OpenAI output focuses on number alignment with different formatting.
- User xuzexin-hz suggests the issue may be due to different interfaces used (`/chat/completions` vs `/completions`).
- Confirmed as a bug in LangChain, not related to user's code or version updates.

**Next Steps:**
- Please confirm if this issue is still relevant to the latest version of the LangChain repository by commenting here.
- If no updates are provided, the issue will be automatically closed in 7 days.

Thank you for your understanding and contribution!

title: __modify_schema__ Method Unsupported in Pydantic v2 Compatibility with Langchain
author: DavidNavarroSaiz
body:
### Checked other resources

- [X] I added a very descriptive title to this issue.
- [X] I searched the LangChain documentation with the integrated search.

- [X] I am sure that this is a bug in LangChain rather than my code.
- [X] The bug is not resolved by updating to the latest stable version of LangChain (or the specific integration package).

### Example Code

Steps to Reproduce
Set up a MongoDB Atlas Vector Store using the MongoDBAtlasVectorSearch and OpenAIEmbeddings from Langchain libraries.

Attempt to run a similarity search with the following code snippet:
```

        db_name = os.getenv("VECTOR_DB_NAME")
        collection_name = os.getenv("VECTOR_DB_COLLECTION_NAME")
        index_name = os.getenv("VECTOR_DBVECTOR_DB_INDEX_NAMENAME")
        # Initialize MongoDB client
        self.client = MongoClient(mongodb_uri)
        self.db = self.client[db_name]
        self.collection = self.db[collection_name]
        self.index_name = index_name

        # Initialize embeddings model
        self.embeddings = OpenAIEmbeddings(model="text-embedding-3-small")

        # Initialize the vector store
        self.vector_store = MongoDBAtlasVectorSearch(
            collection=self.collection,
            embedding=self.embeddings,
            index_name=self.index_name,
            text_key="page_content",
            relevance_score_fn="cosine",
        )
query = "cual empresa es demandada?"
 results = self.vector_store.similarity_search(query=query)
```

### Description

When running a similarity search using langchain_openai, I'm encountering issues related to Pydantic compatibility with Langchain. It appears the library still relies on Pydantic v1 imports and methods, specifically the __modify_schema__ method, which is deprecated in Pydantic v2. The error suggests replacing __modify_schema__ with __get_pydantic_json_schema__, as the method is not supported in Pydantic v2.

Hello, Can you try the following and see if it helps, basically initalizes using `from_connection_string`

```python

from langchain_openai.embeddings import OpenAIEmbeddings
from langchain_community.vectorstores import MongoDBAtlasVectorSearch
from pymongo import MongoClient
db_name = "test"
collection_name = "test_collection"
index_name = "test_index"

# Initialize embeddings model
embeddings = OpenAIEmbeddings(model="text-embedding-3-small")
vector_store = MongoDBAtlasVectorSearch.from_connection_string("<your_connection_string>", "sample_mflix.embedded_movies", embeddings, index_name="_id_",
    text_key="page_content",
    relevance_score_fn="cosine")
query = "Plots"
results = vector_store.similarity_search(query=query)

```

try this:
`pip install --upgrade langchain-openai`

    # æ­¤ä¸ºé»˜è®¤è·¯å¾„ï¼Œæ‚¨å¯æ ¹æ®ä¸šåŠ¡æ‰€åœ¨åœ°åŸŸè¿›è¡Œé…ç½®
    base_url="https://ark.cn-beijing.volces.com/api/v3",
    # ä»ŽçŽ¯å¢ƒå˜é‡ä¸­èŽ·å–æ‚¨çš„Keyé‰´æƒã€‚æ­¤ä¸ºé»˜è®¤æ–¹å¼ï¼Œæ‚¨å¯æ ¹æ®éœ€è¦è¿›è¡Œä¿®æ”¹
    ak=os.getenv("AK"),
    sk=os.getenv("SK"),
)

# Non-streaming:
print("----- standard request -----")
completion = client.chat.completions.create(
    # æŒ‡å®šæ‚¨åˆ›å»ºçš„æ–¹èˆŸæŽ¨ç†æŽ¥å…¥ç‚¹ IDï¼Œæ­¤å¤„å·²å¸®æ‚¨ä¿®æ”¹ä¸ºæ‚¨çš„æŽ¨ç†æŽ¥å…¥ç‚¹ ID
    model=os.getenv("DOUBAO_LITE_MODEL"),
    messages=[
        {"role": "system", "content": "ä½ æ˜¯äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½åŠ©æ‰‹"},
        {"role": "user", "content": "å¸¸è§çš„åå­—èŠ±ç§‘æ¤ç‰©æœ‰å“ªäº›ï¼Ÿ"},
    ],

    # å…è´¹å¼€å¯æŽ¨ç†ä¼šè¯åº”ç”¨å±‚åŠ å¯†ï¼Œè®¿é—® https://www.volcengine.com/docs/82379/1389905 äº†è§£æ›´å¤š
    extra_headers={'x-is-encrypted': 'true'},
)
print(completion.choices[0].message.content)

# Streaming:
print("----- streaming request -----")
stream = client.chat.completions.create(
    # æŒ‡å®šæ‚¨åˆ›å»ºçš„æ–¹èˆŸæŽ¨ç†æŽ¥å…¥ç‚¹ IDï¼Œæ­¤å¤„å·²å¸®æ‚¨ä¿®æ”¹ä¸ºæ‚¨çš„æŽ¨ç†æŽ¥å…¥ç‚¹ ID
    model=os.getenv("DOUBAO_LITE_MODEL"),
    messages=[
        {"role": "system", "content": "ä½ æ˜¯äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½åŠ©æ‰‹"},
        {"role": "user", "content": "å¸¸è§çš„åå­—èŠ±ç§‘æ¤ç‰©æœ‰å“ªäº›ï¼Ÿ"},
    ],

    # å…è´¹å¼€å¯æŽ¨ç†ä¼šè¯åº”ç”¨å±‚åŠ å¯†ï¼Œè®¿é—® https://www.volcengine.com/docs/82379/1389905 äº†è§£æ›´å¤š
    extra_headers={'x-is-encrypted': 'true'},
    # å“åº”å†…å®¹æ˜¯å¦æµå¼è¿”å›ž
    stream=True,
)
for chunk in stream:
    if not chunk.choices:
        continue
    print(chunk.choices[0].delta.content, end="")
print()

```
